conversation.content: [quietly] The blast pattern's still mapped across my face, Doctor Chen, like a roadmap of that day in Kandahar when everything went wrong.
[respectfully] I've reviewed your medical files and the field hospital photos, and I want you to know that what we're discussing today is entirely reconstructive, not cosmetic.
Three of my squad didn't make it out of that Humvee, and here I am worried about whether I'll look normal again. [bitter laugh]
[gently] Survivor's guilt is something I see in many veterans, but wanting to recognize yourself in the mirror isn't vanity—it's part of healing, part of reclaiming who you are.
My daughter, she's seven now, and she still flinches when she sees the left side of my face in direct sunlight.
[measured] The scar tissue can be significantly reduced, and we can restore much of the original bone structure using grafts from your hip, though I won't promise perfection.
Perfection. [hollow laugh]
[carefully] The pioneering techniques we're using now weren't available even five years ago—3D printed scaffolds, nerve regeneration protocols that can restore sensation you've probably lost.
Rodriguez and Murphy had families too, kids who won't see their fathers again, and I get to sit here discussing nerve regeneration. [exhales]

You protected your squad for three years before that day, and from what I understand from your commanding officer, you pulled two wounded soldiers out after the explosion, despite your injuries. [pause]
[defensive] That's just what you do, what any of us would have done—it doesn't make me special or deserving of some miracle surgery.
This isn't about deserving or not deserving; it's about giving you the tools to move forward, to be present for that seven-year-old daughter who needs her father whole.
[strained] Whole.
The procedures will take multiple stages over eighteen months, and there will be significant pain during recovery, but based on similar cases, we can achieve remarkable results.
[quietly] Sometimes I wonder if keeping the scars would be more honest, like wearing the truth of what happened instead of trying to erase it. [sighs]
We're not erasing anything.
[softer] Every morning I trace these scars and remember the exact moment the IED detonated, the sound Garcia made, the way the world went silent and orange.
The memories won't change regardless of what we do surgically, but you deserve to choose how you present yourself to the world, not have that choice made by shrapnel.
[wavering] My wife says I hide behind these scars now, use them as a wall to keep everyone at distance, even her.
[warmly] The surgery is just one part of the journey, and I work closely with trauma counselors who specialize in combat veterans—this is about healing more than skin deep.

scenario: A combat veteran meets with the plastic surgeon who will reconstruct their face after an IED explosion that killed three of their squad members.
